title: Parliamentary group recommends double jeopardy law change in wake of Bob Higgins case
text:
The campaign to reform the double jeopardy law so that sexual offenders like former Southampton and Peterborough United coach Bob Higgins could potentially face retrial for previous abuse allegations has taken a major step forward.

The All-Party Parliamentary Group for adult survivors of childhood sexual abuse, which is chaired by Sarah Champion, has formally recommended a change to the law which would include all forms of child sexual abuse among those most serious crimes that could be retried in the event of compelling new evidence.

It follows a campaign by the former Southampton footballer Dean Radford who, as an 18-year-old in 1989, came forward to allege sexual abuse by Higgins, who was then coaching schoolboy footballers at Southampton.

Five other Southampton players also alleged indecent assault but Higgins pleaded not guilty and was acquitted in January 1992. He then continued working in football - abusing teenage boys at Peterborough, where he worked between 1994 and 1996 - until the scandal of child sexual abuse emerged in 2016 and, as revealed last week by Telegraph Sport, 95 people came forward to allege abuse by Higgins. Of those, 82 were prior to 1989 and nine alleged abuse at Peterborough United.
